Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Spencer D. Dowdall is "Geometry and dynamics in surface topology." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Chicago, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Christopher J. Leininger.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied dynamical and geometric aspects of several naturally occurring objects in abstract mathematics. A main focus was to explore the concept of "hyperbolicity" in several settings. Hyperbolicity is a general phenomenon that occurs throughout mathematics and in nature. While its precise formulation and meaning varies from context to context, it is associated with exponential growth and a rapid spreading out. For example, in the usual Euclidean geometry we live in, if two laser beams are emitted from a common source with very small (say 1 degree) angle between them, then the beams will stay near each other for a very long distance. Were the same setup instead situated in hyperbolic geometry, the two laser beams would very quickly diverge from each other so that just a short distance away from the source the two beams would effectively seem to point in opposite directions. This characteristic type of divergence can be witnessed, for example, on the leaves of kale plants.

This type of hyperbolic behavior turns out to have important and powerful implications for the systems in which it arises. While this project investigated other topics as well, much of the work done in this project strove to quantify and detect hyperbolicity in different settings. Two examples of this are briefly described here:

It is common in mathematics to study moduli spaces or parameter spaces of different objects. For example, one might have 3 robots working in and free to move about a square factory floor. The robots can occupy any position on the factory floor, with the condition that two robots cannot be in the same place at the same time. The resulting set of all legal configurations of the three robots is called the configuration space of the system, and viewing this as an abstract mathematical object allows one to study it via many different tools and branches of mathematics. For example, this configuration space has a very interesting topological structure and enjoys connections both to braids and to polynomials. One particular moduli space of interest is the parameter space of certain geometric structures that one may construct on a given abstract surface. This is known as the Teichmüller space of the surface, and it carries an intrinsic geometry in which the distance between two points reflects how dissimilar their corresponding geometric structures are. The geometry of Teichmüller space has been studied for decades and is well-known to exhibit many aspects of hyperbolicity. In fact, about half a century ago it was thought that Teichmüller space was a hyperbolic space, and this had many far-reaching implications for the study of surface topology. However, that claimed hyperbolicity turned out to be false, and Teichmüller space is now known to be emphatically not hyperbolic. Nevertheless, as Teichmüller space still does exhibit several features of hyperbolicity, it is natural to ask how prevalent this hyperbolic behavior is. On facet of this project addressed exactly this question. By taking a statistical approach, the PI and his coauthors quantified the prevalence of certain hyperbolic behavior in Teichmüller space and showed that the geometry behaves hyperbolically on average.

A second aspect of hyperbolicity explored in this project involves group extensions. Groups are one of the most basic and fundamental algebraic notions in mathematics. For mathematicians, a group is simply a set with a binary operation satisfying a few key properties. In the 1980s Mikhail Gromov introduced the notion of a hyperbolic group, which is roughly a group whose intrinsic geometry exhibits, in a precise way, the hyperbolic phenomenon indicated above. Since their introduction, hyperbolic groups have been hugely influential and now play a central role in the mathematical subfield of geometric group theory. A group extension is a basic and very flexible construction by which one takes two groups and combines them to form a new group (termed the extension group). With these two concepts -- of hyperbolic groups and of group extensions -- it is natural to ask the following: Given two hyperbolic groups, when and how can they be combined so that the resulting extension group is also hyperbolic? This project investigated this question in the specific setting of free group extensions (in which one of the two input groups is a special type of group known as a free group). With his coauthors, the PI introduced explicit and (and robustly achievable) conditions that imply a given free group extension is hyperbolic. Research conducted in this project also discovered and clarified fine geometric features of these free group extensions and made steps towards characterizing exactly which free group extensions are hyperbolic.
